instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
Hello. I have a 17" 2009 Macbook Pro (logic board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I believe). For the past few years it was having trouble starting up and then it would shut off quickly. Occasionally it would boot completely and then it would work fine for days. A few months ago it stopped starting up completely. I read on a forum about how this could be due to the infamous <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> capacitor. I followed the heat test and put it on the radiator. The computer then booted up, so I then got a few of this capacitor: 330 uf 1362J - d

[URL]https://www.mobilesentrix.ca/capacitor-ic-for-macbook-pro-unibody-13-15-17-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-1297-<CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>-330uf-2v-b2-sm[/URL]

Initially I installed the capacitor after moving the 2R2 L7770 coil to make room for it. When I was removing the original tantalum capacitor I tried moving it before it was hot enough and partially detached the + lead pad on the logic board. I tried smoothing over the *partial* break with solder. The replacement cap measured got a 0.3 volt reading with the multimeter, which obviously wasn't good. 

Trying again I wanted to make sure that the capacitor was properly attached to the partially damaged pad. I tried attaching another capacitor with wires and then I hooked the negative lead wire to a screw hole (just to try something new), but got the same 0.3 V reading. 

If the new cap is measuring 0.3 V, then maybe that suggests that the original problem wasn't the capacitor, or that there are more problems? I didn't test the tantalum cap because I assumed that it had been the culprit based on the symptoms.

I read on another post that the L7770 2R2 coil should be returning a 1 V reading. I got a 0.1 V reading from it - could I have broken the coil with excessive heat from the hot air rework station? Here are the photos of the repair:

[MEDIA=imgur]a/wNBtyxj[/MEDIA] 

Anyone have any ideas as to what could've gone wrong? Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

You've probably destroyed something on the board.
That filter cap requires very short conections to its place.
Needs to have very low ESR value and Mouser has it in stock.
NEVER use hot air again in that area!
Lift one pin first, or use JBC/WELLER tweezer.

Be very carefull if you replace it with bigger size cap.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message: Thanks! Good to know about the need for short connections. Given that the 0.3 V reading was happening before I used the wires (with the cap right on the board), any ideas of where I should start testing to find the potential source of the problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
Board looks really ugly now.
You should check all traces and solder for surrounding components of <CHIP>U7750</CHIP>.
Pay atention to Ra/Rb divider.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
Haha yeah not looking the best. 

By saying I should check the traces and solder, do you mean with the multimeter or just visually to see if everything is intact? 

What's the Ra/Rb divider? Tried looking it up but can't find anything on it. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
Look better at <RESISTOR>R7780</RESISTOR>/81.

Check traces continuity with buzzer (diode mode).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
Cleaned the flux off the board, and after some searching I still can't find what the Ra/Rb divider is. Would you mind explaining?

Just got some super fine multimeter probe adapters for the small chips and I'm in the process of checking the continuity of the traces in the region, will update when I'm done. So far so good.

Could the 2R2 coil have sustained some damage from taking a lot of the heat from the heat gun? What voltage should the coil itself return so I can check it? Also what should the 2R2928F63 chip at L7510 return? I chipped the corner off when I brushed it with the tweezers (visible in pics) while it was still hot from the heat gun. Did I break it?

Thanks again!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
An image is better than 1000 words...
[ATTACH]59653[/ATTACH]
In case of doubt, you can change the coil and other components, if donor board is available.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
Thanks, makes sense.

Maybe I'll get a board for components, but in the meantime what values (voltage, resistance, etc) should I be getting from the 2R2 coil and the component at L7510?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
So if this is the schematic info on L7510, how would I get the values I should expect from the multimeter? Haha sorry I'm a total beginner. Thank you so much! 
[ATTACH type="full"]59660[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message:
2.2uH is the iductance of the coil.
You can check if get 0 ohm between its pins.
However this will not ensure the coil is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> 330uf capacitor still reading 0.3 V after replacement
threads.message: Thanks. Is there no way to be sure besides swapping a new one in?
